form.longName: PhenX PX011502 - Health Insurance Coverage
form.preferredDefinition: The respondent is asked about health insurance coverage. A number of possible types of health care coverage are included, not simply health insurance.

question.questionText: Are you currently covered by any of the following types of health insurance or health coverage plans? a. Insurance through a current or former employer or union (of yours or another family member's). This would include COBRA coverage. (health_insurance_coverage_from_employer)

Are you currently covered by any of the following types of health insurance or health coverage plans? b. Insurance purchased directly from an insurance company (by you or another family member). This would include coverage purchased through an exchange or marketplace, such as HealthCare.gov [IF THE RESPONDENT IS IN A STATE WITH STATE-SPECIFIC NAMES, INSERT [or (INSERT PROGRAM NAME)]]. (health_insurance_coverage_purchased)

Are you currently covered by any of the following types of health insurance or health coverage plans? c. Medicare, for people 65 and older, or people with certain disabilities. (health_insurance_coverage_medicare)

Are you currently covered by any of the following types of health insurance or health coverage plans? d. Medicaid, Medical Assistance (MA), the Children's Health Insurance Program (CHIP), or any kind of state or government-sponsored assistance. plan based on income or a disability. You may know this type of coverage as [IF THE RESPONDENT IS IN A STATE WITH STATE-SPECIFIC NAMES INSERT PROGRAM NAME]. (health_insurance_coverage_medicaid)

Are you currently covered by any of the following types of health insurance or health coverage plans? e. TRICARE or other military health care, including VA health care. (health_insurance_coverage_military)
Are you currently covered by any of the following types of health insurance or health coverage plans? f. Indian Health Service. (health_insurance_coverage_indian)

Are you currently covered by any of the following types of health insurance or health coverage plans? g. Any other type of health insurance. coverage or health coverage plan (health_insurance_coverage_other)

Does this mean you currently have no health insurance or health coverage plan? In answering this question, please exclude plans that pay for only one type of service (such as, nursing home care, accidents, family planning, or dental care) and plans that only provide extra cash when hospitalized. (health_insurance_coverage_nocoverage)

instruction.text: [health_insurance_coverage_from_employer] <> '1' or [health_insurance_coverage_purchased] <> '1' or [health_insurance_coverage_medicare] <> '1' or [health_insurance_coverage_medicaid] <> '1' or [health_insurance_coverage_military] <> '1' or [health_insurance_coverage_indian] <> '1' or [health_insurance_coverage_other] <> '1'

validValue.description: I do NOT have health insurance

validValue.meaningText: I HAVE some kind of health insurance
validValue.description: I HAVE some kind of health insurance

question.questionText: What type of health insurance do you have? (health_insurance_coverage_type)

form.longName: PhenX PX030804 - Tobacco 30day Quantity And Frequency Adult
form.preferredDefinition: Measurement of respondent's 30-day frequency of use of drugs. Measures used to calculate the respondent's 30-day quantity and frequency use of cigarettes. For the adult respondent, there are three sets of question protocols: (1) a protocol for Every-Day Smokers, (2) a protocol for Some-Day Smokers, and (3) a protocol for Former Smokers.

question.questionText: On the average, about how many cigarettes do you now smoke each day? (everyday_smoker_quantity_1day)
On how many of the past 30 days did you smoke cigarettes? (someday_smoker_days_1month)
Would you say you smoked on AT LEAST 12 DAYS in the past 30 days? (someday_smoker_days_1month_minimum)
On the average, on those [C1 days IF entry for C1 NE D/R. OR AT LEAST 12 days IF C1i=1 YES] days (someday_smoker_quantity_1day)
About how long has it been since you COMPLETELY quit smoking cigarettes? (former_smoker_quit_smoking)
About how long has it been since you COMPLETELY quit smoking cigarettes? Units (former_smoker_quit_smoking_units)
Have you EVER smoked cigarettes EVERY DAY for at least 6 months? (former_smoker_six_months)
When you last smoked every day, on average how many cigarettes did you smoke each day? (former_smoker_past_habit)

protocol.preferredDefinition: Measurement of respondent's 30-day frequency of use of drugs. Measures used to calculate the respondent's 30-day quantity and frequency use of cigarettes. For the adult respondent, there are three sets of question protocols: (1) a protocol for Every-Day Smokers, (2) a protocol for Some-Day Smokers, and (3) a protocol for Former Smokers.

form.longName: PhenX PX031102 - Substances Lifetime Use
form.preferredDefinition: Respondents answer questions from the National Epidemiologic Survey on Alcohol and Related Conditions-III (NESARC-III) related to their lifetime use of illicit and prescribed substances.

question.questionText: Have you EVER used any of these medicines or drugs? Read list. (If "YES" to any drug category, ask: Which ones?) Record specific drug(s) used. (substances_lifetime_use_read_list)

Have you EVER used any of these medicines or drugs? Sedatives or tranquilizers, for example - barbs, downers, Ami-bee-en, Lunesta, phenobarbital, pentobarbital, Hali-see-on, Tuinal, Nembutal, Seconal, Librium, Valium, Xanax, benzodiayzi-a-peens, tranks, Ativan. (substances_lifetime_use_sedatives)

Have you EVER used any of these medicines or drugs? Painkillers, for example - methadone, codeine, Demerol, Vyi-ko-din, Oxi-koni-tin, opium, oxy, Peri-ko-set, Dill-oddi-id, Peri-ko-dan, morphine. (substances_lifetime_use_painkillers)
Have you EVER used any of these medicines or drugs? Mariwai-na, including THC, for example - weed, pot, dope, hashish, Mary Jane, joint, blunt. (substances_lifetime_use_mariwaina)
Have you EVER used any of these medicines or drugs? Cocaine or crack, for example - blow, rock, snow. (substances_lifetime_use_cocaine)

Have you EVER used any of these medicines or drugs? Stimulants, for example - Addi-erall, Concerta, Syi-lert, Pro-vigi-il, Ritalin or Dexedrine, speed, amphetamine, methamphetamine, uppers, bennies, pep pills, crystal, crank. (substances_lifetime_use_stimulants)
Have you EVER used any of these medicines or drugs? Club drugs, for example - MDMA, ecstasy, GHB, Ro-hipi-nol, ketti-amine, Special K, XTC, roofies. (substances_lifetime_use_club_drugs)

Have you EVER used any of these medicines or drugs? Hallucinogens, for example - LSD, acid, PCP, mescaline, pay-oi-tee, sillosyi-bin, mushrooms, angel dust, cactus. (substances_lifetime_use_hallucinogens)

Have you EVER used any of these medicines or drugs? Inhalants or solvents, for example - nitrous oxide, lighter fluid, gasoline, cleaning fluid, glue, poppers, whippets. (substances_lifetime_use_inhalants_)
Have you EVER used any of these medicines or drugs? Heroin, for example - smack, black tar, poppy. (substances_lifetime_use_heroin)
Have you EVER used any of these medicines or drugs? Any OTHER medicines or drugs, for example - steroids, Elavil, Thoarazine, or Haldol. (substances_lifetime_use_other)
Is at least one category marked in 1a? (substances_lifetime_use_classify_user)

protocol.preferredDefinition: Respondents answer questions from the National Epidemiologic Survey on Alcohol and Related Conditions-III (NESARC-III) related to their lifetime use of illicit and prescribed substances.

form.longName: PhenX PX090202 - Arterial Blood Gas Abg
form.preferredDefinition: This protocol describes the procedures for blood collection for arterial blood gas (ABG) analysis. It involves puncturing an artery with a thin needle and syringe and drawing a small volume of blood. The most common puncture site is the radial artery at the wrist, but sometimes the femoral artery in the groin or other sites is used.

question.questionText: What blood drawn anaerobically from a peripheral artery via a single percutaneous needle puncture or from an indwelling arterial cannula or catheter for multiple samples? (arterial_blood_gas_draw_conditions)
What is today's date? (arterial_blood_gas_date)
What is the time of sample collection? (arterial_blood_gas_time_sample_collection)
What is the patient's body temperature? (arterial_blood_gas_patient_body_temperature)
What is the patient's position when blood was drawn? (arterial_blood_gas_patient_body_position)
Please describe the patient's activity level. (arterial_blood_gas_patient_activity_level)
What is the patient's respiratory rate? (arterial_blood_gas_patient_respiratory_rate)
What is the sample site? (arterial_blood_gas_patient_sample_site)
What are the results of the Allen test? (arterial_blood_gas_patient_results_allen_test)
What is the inspired oxygen concentration? (arterial_blood_gas_inspired_oxygen_concentration)
What is the supplemental oxygen flow? (arterial_blood_gas_supplemental_oxygen)
What is the mode of supported ventilation? (arterial_blood_gas_mode_supported_ventilation)

protocol.preferredDefinition: This protocol describes the procedures for blood collection for arterial blood gas (ABG) analysis. It involves puncturing an artery with a thin needle and syringe and drawing a small volume of blood. The most common puncture site is the radial artery at the wrist, but sometimes the femoral artery in the groin or other sites is used.

form.longName: PhenX PX090402 - Chest Computed Tomography Ct
form.preferredDefinition: Chest computed tomography (CT) is a non-invasive test that shows the size, shape, and structure of the lungs and other structures in the thorax. The chest CT scanning machine takes many pictures, called slices, of the lungs and the inside of the chest. A computer processes these pictures to be viewed on a monitor or printed on film. The computer can also stack the pictures to create a detailed, three-dimensional (3D) model of the organs. This 3D digital information can be used to measure the dimensions of the structure, such as the bronchial tree, or the density of the structure, such as the lung parenchyma. It is important that the CT scanner used in any clinical research study be calibrated regularly against calibration standards that are provided by the manufacturer or in some instances by the study itself.

question.questionText: Has the subject's identity been confirmed? (chest_computed_tomography_subject_identity)
Has the subject removed all metallic devices from the chest area? (chest_computed_tomography_subject_remove_metal_devices)
Has the subject been informed of the importance of compliance with the breathing instructions? (chest_computed_tomography_subject_informed_compliance_instructions)
Was at least one rehearsal of the end-inspiratory breath-hold performed? (chest_computed_tomography_subject_rehearsal_breath_hold)
Were scans reconstructed using the edge enhancing and smooth algorithms? (chest_computed_tomography_scan_algorithms)
Were contiguous end-expiratory CT images obtained? (chest_computed_tomography_scan_contiguous_expiratory_ct_images)
Was the subject allowed to breathe and relax for at least 15 seconds while preparing to take a CT scan of the lungs? (chest_computed_tomography_supine_inspiration_preparation)
Was the scan taken during one breath-hold at full-inspiration (chest_computed_tomography_supine_inspiration_breath_hold)
Was the subject allowed to breathe and relax for at least 15 seconds while preparing to take a CT scan of the lungs? (chest_computed_tomography_supine_expiration_preparation)
Was the scan taken during one breath-hold at expiration as quickly as possible? (chest_computed_tomography_supine_expiration_breath_hold)

protocol.preferredDefinition: Chest computed tomography (CT) is a non-invasive test that shows the size, shape, and structure of the lungs and other structures in the thorax. The chest CT scanning machine takes many pictures, called slices, of the lungs and the inside of the chest. A computer processes these pictures to be viewed on a monitor or printed on film. The computer can also stack the pictures to create a detailed, three-dimensional (3D) model of the organs. This 3D digital information can be used to measure the dimensions of the structure, such as the bronchial tree, or the density of the structure, such as the lung parenchyma. It is important that the CT scanner used in any clinical research study be calibrated regularly against calibration standards that are provided by the manufacturer or in some instances by the study itself.

form.longName: PhenX PX091602 - Spirometry Child
form.preferredDefinition: The procedures for performing spirometry with a child are very similar to those for performing spirometry with an adult. However, young children require more training and visual cues (e.g., animation), and they may have a greater number of unsuccessful spirometry test maneuvers. The results from children's spirometry tests are also more variable than those from adults' tests.

question.questionText: Was the child allowed put the mouthpiece into his/her mouth and blow with the nose clip on the nose? (spirometry_preschool_child_mouthpiece_nose_clip)
Was a nose clip used? (spirometry_preschool_child_nose_clip)
Was the child provided a demonstration and encouraged to inspire fully into the spirometer and blow fast? (spirometry_preschool_child_demonstration)
Which position is the child in during this test? (spirometry_preschool_child_position)
Was the manuever successful? The child should have at least two to three successful and reproducible maneuvers. (spirometry_preschool_child_manuever_successful)
What is the Forced Vital Capacity (FVC)? (spirometry_preschool_child_forced_vital_capacity)
What is the Forced Expiratory Volume in .5 seconds (FEV.5)? (spirometry_preschool_child_forced_expiratory_volume_5)
What is the Forced Expiratory Volume in .75 seconds (FEV.75)? (spirometry_preschool_child_forced_expiratory_volume_75)
What is the Forced Expiratory Volume in 1 second (FEV1)? (spirometry_preschool_child_forced_expiratory_volume_1)
What is the repeatability of parameters above? (spirometry_preschool_child_repeatability_parameters)
What is the number of satisfactory attempts (maneuvers)? (spirometry_preschool_child_satisfactory_maneuvers_number)

protocol.preferredDefinition: The procedures for performing spirometry with a child are very similar to those for performing spirometry with an adult. However, young children require more training and visual cues (e.g., animation), and they may have a greater number of unsuccessful spirometry test maneuvers. The results from children's spirometry tests are also more variable than those from adults' tests.

form.longName: PhenX PX101202 - Prostate Symptoms
form.preferredDefinition: The interviewer asks the male participant to complete the questionnaire, which includes questions about how often he urinates at night, whether he has incomplete bladder emptying, urinary frequency, urinary urgency, difficulty urinating and also about the quality of life associated with urination. Note that the questions in this protocol, the International Prostate Symptom Score (I-PSS), were previously called the American Urological Association Symptom Index.

question.questionText: In the past month: (Incomplete emptying) How often have you had the sensation of not emptying your bladder? (prostate_symptoms_incomplete_emptying_past_month)
In the past month: (Frequency) How often have you had to urinate less than every two hours? (prostate_symptoms_urination_frequency_past_month)
In the past month: (Intermittency) How often have you found you stopped and started again several times when you urinated? (prostate_symptoms_urination_intermittency_past_month)
In the past month: (Urgency) How often have you found it difficult to postpone urination? (prostate_symptoms_urination_urgency_past_month)
In the past month: (Weak stream) How often have you had a weak urinary stream? (prostate_symptoms_urination_weak_stream_past_month)
In the past month: (Straining) How often have you had to strain to start urination? (prostate_symptoms_urination_straining_past_month)
In the past month: (Nocturia) How many times did you typically get up at night to urinate? (prostate_symptoms_urination_nocturia_past_month)
If you were to spend the rest of your life with your urinary condition just the way it is now, how would you feel about that? (prostate_symptoms_quality_life_assessment_scale)

protocol.preferredDefinition: The interviewer asks the male participant to complete the questionnaire, which includes questions about how often he urinates at night, whether he has incomplete bladder emptying, urinary frequency, urinary urgency, difficulty urinating and also about the quality of life associated with urination. Note that the questions in this protocol, the International Prostate Symptom Score (I-PSS), were previously called the American Urological Association Symptom Index.

Sperm morphology (normal forms, strict criteria) (male_fertility_status_sperm_morphology)
pH (male_fertility_status_sperm_acidity)
Peroxidase-positive leukocytes (male_fertility_status_peroxidase_positive_leukocytes)

Immunobead test (motile spermatozoa with bound beads (male_fertility_status_motile_spermatozoa_immunobead_test)
Seminal zinc (male_fertility_status_seminal_zinc)
Seminal fructose (male_fertility_status_seminal_fructose)

form.longName: PhenX PX121702 - Depression Questionnaire Children
form.preferredDefinition: The Mood and Feelings Questionnaire (MFQ) is a 13-item, self-administered questionnaire on depressive symptoms. Each item is rated on a 3-point scale (0 = not true; 1 = sometimes true; 2 = true), and total scores range from 0-26, with higher scores indicating more severe depression symptoms.

question.questionText: I felt miserable or unhappy. (depression_questionnaire_children_felt_miserable)
I didn't enjoy anything at all. (depression_questionnaire_children_enjoy)
I felt so tired I just sat around and did nothing. (depression_questionnaire_children_sat_around)
I was very restless. (depression_questionnaire_children_restless)
I felt I was no good anymore. (depression_questionnaire_children_no_good)
I cried a lot. (depression_questionnaire_children_cried)
I found it hard to think properly or concentrate. (depression_questionnaire_children_hard_to_think)
I hated myself. (depression_questionnaire_children_hate_myself)
I was a bad person. (depression_questionnaire_children_bad_person)
I felt lonely. (depression_questionnaire_children_felt_lonely)
I thought nobody really loved me. (depression_questionnaire_children_loved_me)
I thought I could never be as good as other kids. (depression_questionnaire_children_good_other_kids)
I did everything wrong. (depression_questionnaire_children_everything_wrong)

protocol.preferredDefinition: The Mood and Feelings Questionnaire (MFQ) is a 13-item, self-administered questionnaire on depressive symptoms. Each item is rated on a 3-point scale (0 = not true; 1 = sometimes true; 2 = true), and total scores range from 0-26, with higher scores indicating more severe depression symptoms.

form.longName: PhenX PX130402 - Epilepsy Screener Child Proxy
form.preferredDefinition: The Family History of Epilepsy Screening Interview is a nine-item, interviewer-administered questionnaire to screen for the presence of epilepsy in family members, including children and those who are deceased.

question.questionText: Did anyone ever tell you that (he/she) had a seizure or convulsion caused by a high fever when (he/she) was a child? (epilepsy_screener_child_proxy_seizure_convulsion_high_fever)

(Other than the seizure/s) (he/she) had because of a high fever) Has (he/she) ever had, or has anyone ever told you that (he/she) had, a seizure disorder or epilepsy? (epilepsy_screener_child_proxy_seizure_disorder_epilepsy)

(Other than the seizure/s) (he/she) had because of a high fever) Has (he/she) ever had, or has anyone ever told you that (he/she) had, any of the following... A seizure, convulsion, fit, or spell under any circumstances? (epilepsy_screener_child_proxy_seizure_convulsion_fit_spell_circumstances)

(Other than the seizure/s) (he/she) had because of a high fever) Has (he/she) ever had, or has anyone ever told you that (he/she) had, any of the following... Uncontrolled movements of part or all of (his/her) body such as twitching, jerking, shaking, or going limp? (epilepsy_screener_child_proxy_uncontrolled_movements)

(Other than the seizure/s) (he/she) had because of a high fever) Has (he/she) ever had, or has anyone ever told you that (he/she) had, any of the following... An unexplained change in (his/her) mental state or level of awareness, or an episode of "spacing out" that (he/she) could not control? (epilepsy_screener_child_proxy_unexplained_change)

(Other than the seizure/s) (he/she) had because of a high fever) Has (he/she) ever had, or has anyone ever told you that (he/she) had, any of the following... Did anyone ever tell you that when (he/she) was a small child, (he/she) would daydream or stare into space more than other children? (epilepsy_screener_child_proxy_small_child_daydream_stare)

(Other than the seizure/s) (he/she) had because of a high fever) Has (he/she) ever had, or has anyone ever told you that (he/she) had, any of the following... Has (he/she) ever noticed any unusual body movements or feelings when exposed to strobe lights, video games, flickering lights, or sun glare? (epilepsy_screener_child_proxy_unusual_body_movements_strobe_lights_video_games_flickering_sun)

(Other than the seizure/s) (he/she) had because of a high fever) Has (he/she) ever had, or has anyone ever told you that (he/she) had, any of the following... Shortly after waking up, either in the morning or after a nap, has (he/she) ever noticed uncontrollable jerking or clumsiness, such as dropping things or things suddenly "flying" from (his/her) hands? (epilepsy_screener_child_proxy_shortly_after_waking_up)

(Other than the seizure/s) (he/she) had because of a high fever) Has (he/she) ever had, or has anyone ever told you that (he/she) had, any of the following... Has (he/she) ever had any other type of repeated unusual spells? (epilepsy_screener_child_proxy_other_type_repeated_unusual_spells)

protocol.preferredDefinition: The Family History of Epilepsy Screening Interview is a nine-item, interviewer-administered questionnaire to screen for the presence of epilepsy in family members, including children and those who are deceased.

form.longName: PhenX PX130502 - Pediatric Migraine Disability Assessment Pedmidas
form.preferredDefinition: The Pediatric Migraine Disability Assessment (PedMIDAS) headache disability questionnaire is completed by the patient and his/her parent and is reviewed with the clinician or study staff. It captures the impact of headaches on school performance (three questions), activities at home (one question on homework or chores), and social and/or sports functions (two questions). The PedMIDAS is scored by summing the answers across the six questions. If a range is provided as an answer, either use the high end of the range or prompt for a single answer. The frequency and severity are not scored but can be used for clinical reference.

question.questionText: How many full school days of school were missed in the last 3 months due to headaches? (MigrainePediatrics_Missed_Full_SchoolDays_Past3Months)
How many partial days of school were missed in the last 3 months due to headaches (do not include full days counted in the first question)? (MigrainePediatrics_Missed_Partial_SchoolDays_Past3Months)

How many days in the last 3 months did you function at less than half your ability in school because of a headache (do not include days counted in the first two questions)? (MigrainePediatrics_Function_LessThan_Ability_Past3Months)
How many days were you not able to do things at home (i.e., chores, homework, etc.) due to a headache? (MigrainePediatrics_Days_Unable_Function_AtHome)
How many days did you not participate in other activities due to headaches (i.e., play, go out, sports, etc.)? (MigrainePediatrics_Days_Unable_Participate_InActivities)

How many days did you participate in these activities, but functioned at less than half your ability (do not include days counted in the 5th question)? (MigrainePediatrics_Function_LessThan_Ability_InActivities)
Headache Frequency (MigrainePediatrics_Headache_Frequency)
Headache Severity (MigrainePediatrics_Headache_Severity)

protocol.preferredDefinition: The Pediatric Migraine Disability Assessment (PedMIDAS) headache disability questionnaire is completed by the patient and his/her parent and is reviewed with the clinician or study staff. It captures the impact of headaches on school performance (three questions), activities at home (one question on homework or chores), and social and/or sports functions (two questions). The PedMIDAS is scored by summing the answers across the six questions. If a range is provided as an answer, either use the high end of the range or prompt for a single answer. The frequency and severity are not scored but can be used for clinical reference.

form.longName: PhenX PX130802 - Verbal Memory Child
form.preferredDefinition: The Children's Memory ScaleTM (CMS) assesses a range of memory function in children and includes short- and long-term visual and verbal memory and executive working memory tasks. The verbal memory subtest includes three tasks: Stories, Word Pairs, and Word Lists.

Did the child answer the yes/no questions correctly for Story #2? (verbal_memory_child_stories_immediate_questions2)
Did the child repeat each story 30 minutes after it was told? (verbal_memory_child_stories_delayed)
Did the child answer the yes/no questions correctly for Story #1? (verbal_memory_child_stories_delayed_questions1)
Did the child answer the yes/no questions correctly for Story #2? (verbal_memory_child_stories_delayed_questions2)
How many word pairs did the child repeat immediately after being read three repetitions of word pairs? (verbal_memory_child_word_pairs_learning_immediate)
How many word pairs did the child repeat 30 minutes after being read three repetitions of word pairs? (verbal_memory_child_word_pairs_learning_delayed)
How many word pairs did the child correctly recognize to be part of the original list? (verbal_memory_child_word_pairs_learning_delayed_recognition)
Immediately after being given the distractor list, how many words did the child correctly repeat from the first word list? (verbal_memory_child_word_list_immediate)
Thirty minutes after being given the distractor list, how many words did the child correctly repeat from the first word list? (verbal_memory_child_word_list_delayed)
How many specific words did the child correctly recognize to be part of the original list? (verbal_memory_child_word_list_delayed_recognition)

protocol.preferredDefinition: The Children's Memory ScaleTM (CMS) assesses a range of memory function in children and includes short- and long-term visual and verbal memory and executive working memory tasks. The verbal memory subtest includes three tasks: Stories, Word Pairs, and Word Lists.

form.longName: PhenX PX190902 - Adolescent Pediatric Pain Tool Appt
form.preferredDefinition: The Adolescent Pediatric Pain Tool (APPT) is a multidimensional self-administered pain assessment tool. The APPT is used with children and adolescents to evaluate pain intensity, location, and quality (including sensory, temporal, affective, and evaluative). The APPT can be used with individuals experiencing pain for various reasons, such as sickle cell disease (SCD), postoperative pain, allergy testing, orthopedic, traumatic injury, and cancer. The APPT was modeled after the McGill Pain Questionnaire and is available in English and Spanish.

The APPT is used with children and adolescents to evaluate pain intensity, location, and quality (including sensory, temporal, affective, and evaluative). form.longName: PhenX PX211302 - Neighborhood Concentrated Disadvantage
form.preferredDefinition: The protocol is based on extracting data from the U.S. Census Bureau on a set of variables related to the concept of "concentrated disadvantage" (Sampson, Raudenbush, & Earls, 1997). All the relevant variables are available from the long form of the 1990 and 2000 Decennial Censuses (SF3) and from the 5-year American Community Survey (ACS) estimates. ACS estimates are annually updated; current 5-year data sets range from 20052009 to 20102014. Once the data are extracted, an index score of concentrated disadvantage can be calculated at the neighborhood level of interest; this is usually based on census tract or census block group data.

question.questionText: Percent Of Individuals Below The Poverty Line (derived from ACS Table C17002) (percent_below_poverty_line)
Percent of Households Receiving Public Assistance (derived from ACS Table B19057) (percent_on_public_assistance)
Percent Female-Headed Families (derived from ACS Table B11001) (percent_female_headed_households)
Percent Unemployed (derived from ACS Table B23025) (percent_unemployed)
Percent Less Than Age 18 (derived from ACS Table B01001) (percent_younger_than_18)
Percent Black (derived from ACS Table B02001) (percent_black)

form.longName: PhenX PX240401 - Concentrations Of Polychlorinated Biphenyls Pcbs And Per
form.preferredDefinition: Blood is collected from the subject in a pre-screened 3 ml red top tube and is not inverted or mixed and kept upright on a tube rack for 20-30 minutes to allow to coagulate. Centrifuge the red-top tubes for 10 minutes, transfer to Wheaton Bottle, and cap. Place serum samples in a -20 C freezer and store until shipment.Analysis is by high-resolution gas chromatography/isotope-dilution high-resolution mass spectrometry (HRGC/ID-HRMS). This device measures concentrations of polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs) and persistent pesticides in serum.

form.longName: PhenX PX240601 - Current Pregnancy Status Bioassay
form.preferredDefinition: Human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) is a hormone the placenta produces shortly after fertilization. Within 7-10 days of conception, hCG can be detected in urine or blood samples. Levels of hCG rise quickly through early pregnancy and peak at 10-12 weeks in the 100,000 to 200,000 mIU/mL range. Standard urine collection procedures from the National Children's Study are described in the protocol. An immunoassay was used during National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey (NHANES) to rapidly detect pregnancy in adolescents and adults.

question.questionText: Was the collected urine sample a first morning void sample? (pregnancy_bioassay_urine_sample)

Was an immunoassay test kit or a digital pregnancy test kit used? (pregnancy_bioassay_test_type)
What are the results of the pregnancy test? (pregnancy_bioassay_test_results)
Has the patient just missed her period by 1-2 days? (pregnancy_bioassay_period)

form.longName: PhenX PX530602 - Motor And Attentional Impulsivity Immediate And Delayed
form.preferredDefinition: The Immediate and Delayed Memory Task (IMT/DMT) is a computer-based test where participants selectively and rapidly respond to a series of visual stimuli. The Immediate and Delayed Memory Task tracks both commission errors (motor impulsivity), which are responses to incorrect stimuli, and omission errors (attentional impulsivity), which are nonresponses to correct stimuli. For more information about the Immediate Memory Task, please refer to its entry in the Cognitive Atlas http://www.cognitiveatlas.org/task/immediate_memory_task For more information about the Delayed Memory Task, please refer to its entry in the Cognitive Atlas [http://www.cognitiveatlas.org/task/delayed_memory_task

module.longName: Motor And Attentional Impulsivity Immediate And Delayed
module.preferredDefinition: Motor And Attentional Impulsivity Immediate And Delayed

question.questionText: A target stimulus is a 5-digit number that is identical to the preceding number. Responses to target stimuli are recorded as correct detections. How many correct detections were made by the participant? (memory_task_correct_detections)

A filler stimulus is a random 5-digit number that appears whenever a target or catch trial is not scheduled to appear. Responses to filler stimuli are recorded as filler errors. How many filler errors were made by the participant? (memory_task_filler_errors)
What is the rate of correct detections? (memory_task_correct_detections_rate)
What is the rate of commision error responses to catch stimuli? (memory_task_commission_error_rate)
What is the rate of filler errors? (memory_task_filler_errors_rate)
What are the parametric and non-parametric indices or stimulus discriminability? (memory_task_stimulus_discriminability)
What are the parametric and non-parametric indices of response bias (i.e. liberal or conservative resppon (memory_task_response_bias)

form.longName: PhenX PX660901 - Psychiatric Symptoms Frequency
form.preferredDefinition: The modified Colorado Symptom Index (CSI) is a 14-item, self-report scale designed to assess frequency of positive mood and cognitive symptoms. Items are rated on a 5-point Likert-style scale (Not at all, Once during the month, Several times during the month, Several times a week, at least every day). Each item is scored on a 0-4 scale (not at all = 0; at least every day = 4) and added together to give a score between 0 and 56, with higher scores indicating greater frequency of symptoms.

question.questionText: How often have you felt nervous, tense, worried, frustrated, or afraid? (psychiatric_symptoms_tension)
How often have you felt depressed? (psychiatric_symptoms_depressed)
How often have you felt lonely? (psychiatric_symptoms_loneliness)
How often have others told you that you acted paranoid" or "suspicious"?" (psychiatric_symptoms_paranoia_others)
How often did you hear voices, or hear and see things that other people didnt think were there? (psychiatric_symptoms_hallucinations)
How often did you have trouble making up your mind about something, like deciding where you wanted to go or what you were going to do, or how to solve a problem? (psychiatric_symptoms_indecisiveness)

How often did you have trouble thinking straight or concentrating on something you needed to do (like worrying so much or thinking about problems so much that you cant remember or focus on other things)? (psychiatric_symptoms_focus)
How often did you feel that your behavior or actions were strange or different from that of other people? (psychiatric_symptoms_strange_behavior)
How often did you feel out of place or like you did not fit in? (psychiatric_symptoms_social_anxiety)
How often did you forget important things? (psychiatric_symptoms_forgetful)
How often did you have problems with thinking too fast (thoughts racing)? (psychiatric_symptoms_racing_thoughts)
How often did you feel suspicious or paranoid? (psychiatric_symptoms_paranoia)
How often did you feel like hurting or killing yourself? (psychiatric_symptoms_suicidal_thoughts)
How often have you felt like seriously hurting someone else? (psychiatric_symptoms_violent_thoughts)

protocol.preferredDefinition: The modified Colorado Symptom Index (CSI) is a 14-item, self-report scale designed to assess frequency of positive mood and cognitive symptoms. Each item is scored on a 0-4 scale (not at all = 0; at least every day = 4) and added together to give a score between 0 and 56, with higher scores indicating greater frequency of symptoms.

form.longName: PhenX PX661301 - Personal Wellbeing Index Adult
form.preferredDefinition: The Personal Wellbeing Index-Adult (PWI-A) is a seven-item, self-administered scale that measures satisfaction with the following life domains: standard of living, health, life achievement, personal relationships, personal safety, community connectedness, and future security. Each item is rated on a 0-to-10 scale (0 = No satisfaction at all; 10 = Very satisfied). Items can be scored individually to derive a score for the corresponding domain, or all the scores for all items can be summed and averaged to form the Personal Wellbeing Index (PWI).

question.questionText: How satisfied are you with your standard of living? (personal_wellbeing_living_standard)
How satisfied are you with your health? (personal_wellbeing_health)
How satisfied are you with what you are achieving in life? (personal_wellbeing_achievements)
How satisfied are you with your personal relationships? (personal_wellbeing_relationships)
How satisfied are you with how safe you feel? (personal_wellbeing_safety)
How satisfied are you with feeling part of your community? (personal_wellbeing_community)
How satisfied are you with your future security? (personal_wellbeing_security)

protocol.preferredDefinition: The Personal Wellbeing Index-Adult (PWI-A) is a seven-item, self-administered scale that measures satisfaction with the following life domains: standard of living, health, life achievement, personal relationships, personal safety, community connectedness, and future security. Each item is rated on a 0-to-10 scale (0 = No satisfaction at all; 10 = Very satisfied). Items can be scored individually to derive a score for the corresponding domain, or all the scores for all items can be summed and averaged to form the Personal Wellbeing Index (PWI).

form.longName: PhenX PX661302 - Personal Wellbeing Index Child
form.preferredDefinition: The Personal Wellbeing Index-School Children (PWI-SC) is a self-administered scale that includes seven items of happiness corresponding to seven life domains: standard of living, health, life achievement, personal relationships, personal safety, community connectedness, and future security. Each item is rated on a 0- to 10-scale (0 = Very Sad; 10 = Very Happy). Items can be scored individually to derive a score for the corresponding domain or all the scores for all items can be summed and averaged to form the Personal Wellbeing Index (PWI). To create scores that can be compared with one another, the ratings can be converted to a 0- to 100-point scale by shifting the decimal point one place to the right (e.g., a score of 6.5 becomes 65%).

question.questionText: How happy are you about the things you have? Like the money you have and the things you own? (personal_wellbeing_children_possessions)
How happy are you with your health? (personal_wellbeing_children_health)
How happy are you with the things you want to be good at? (personal_wellbeing_children_goals)
How happy are you about getting on with the people you know? (personal_wellbeing_children_relationships)
How happy are you about how safe you feel? (personal_wellbeing_children_safety)
How happy are you about doing things away from your home? (personal_wellbeing_children_outside_home)
How happy are you about what may happen to you later on in your life? (personal_wellbeing_children_life)

protocol.preferredDefinition: The Personal Wellbeing Index-School Children (PWI-SC) is a self-administered scale that includes seven items of happiness corresponding to seven life domains: standard of living, health, life achievement, personal relationships, personal safety, community connectedness, and future security. Each item is rated on a 0- to 10-scale (0 = Very Sad; 10 = Very Happy). Items can be scored individually to derive a score for the corresponding domain or all the scores for all items can be summed and averaged to form the Personal Wellbeing Index (PWI). To create scores that can be compared with one another, the ratings can be converted to a 0- to 100-point scale by shifting the decimal point one place to the right (e.g., a score of 6.5 becomes 65%).

form.longName: PhenX PX662101 - Family Functioning General Functioning Mcmaster Family
form.preferredDefinition: The Family Questionnaire (FQ) is a 20-item, self-administered questionnaire that measures expressed emotion status (criticism and emotional over involvement [EOI]) of family members toward patients with mental illness. The FQ has two subscales: critical comments, and EOI. Each item is rated on a 4-point scale (1 = never/very rarely; 4 = very often). The FQ is scored by adding together the ratings from the individual items, with higher scores indicating greater levels of expressed emotion.
